Raising and Giving makes a comeback

20/11/2022

Nouse speaks to RAG Officer, Ellen Rintoul, and attends the ReFashion show in collaboration with Environment and Ethics

Image by Jasmine Mirza

By Alanah Hammond

Ahead of this edition, Nouse spoke with YUSU Raising andGiving (RAG) Officer, Ellen Rintoul, about her plans for bringing RAG back to York and the recent ReFashion show, which was held in collaboration with the Environment and Ethics network on 6 November.

Ellen is a â€œthird year linguistics studentâ€ and she has taken on the task of bringing RAG back to York this year following Covid-19, which saw it dip. Her plans for this include â€œplanning lots of eventsâ€ including â€œthe sustainable fashion show which is in partnership with Raising and Giving and the Environment and Ethics network and their part time officer Anushka.â€

This year, the RAG beneficiary is IDAS (Independent Domestic Abuse Services) â€œwhich works around North Yorkshire with victims of sexual assault and domestic abuse and also works a lot with students at our University.â€

They said, â€œThis year we decided that we would go with one beneficiary rather than a number of beneficiaries so we could better benefit that one charity and be able to build up a relationship with that charity.â€

The beneficiary was put to a vote among the student body where students were given a choice of five. Ellen explained that IDAS â€œdo some absolutely fantastic work with providing support and counselling after someone has gone through one of those traumatic events.â€

Ellen added, "They help people who are fleeing from their homes, and they are specifically working around the cost of living crisis with how events such as those are probably going to increase.They are doing some really good work and Iâ€™m really happy that the student body voted for them to be our beneficiary.â€

People can get involved with RAG through attending events such as the ReFashion show â€œif they would like to take part in it that wayâ€. There is also a â€œRAG committee which is always open to members so if you would like to do that then get in touch with us via the Instagram.â€

The RAG committee â€œis a brand new thing which has just come in this term,â€ which is headed up by Ellen and there are a group of other students who sit on the committee.

They â€œwork together to create RAG events, look where the funds are going, use social media to advertise our causes and what we are fundraising for, talk to the charities that we are fundraising for and see what they need, talk to [University ofYork] colleges and their RAG officers to see what events are going on around theUniversity.â€

Ultimately, Ellen describes the committee as â€œa group of people who work together on fundraising.â€ She also highlights that â€œif you would like to get involved in RAG in a different way, perhaps setting up an event of your own or doing some fundraising just yourselves, maybe a group of you, maybe a sportsÂ team, then you can do fundraising, you just need to let us know that you are doing that by using the RAG fundraising guide on the YUSU website.â€

Examples given for possible events include a â€œbake sale, a social where everyone dresses as the same colour, anything you can think of, you can turn it into a fundraiser.â€

â€œThere are also two trips abroad next summer: The Elephants and Hill tribes trip to Thailand where people will be going to local communities and helping out in Thailand at a local elephant sanctuary. Then we also have the Nordic wilderness kayaking trip which goes through the national parks of Finland.â€

â€œBoth are really amazing trips and are run by our challenge partner, Challenges Abroad.â€

Anyone willing to take part needs to fundraise for the trips, with funds going to the FutureSense Foundation. The information to sign up can be found on the YUSU RAG Instagram.

Nouse also asked Ellen about future RAG events and whilst she wouldnâ€™t give any details she did say that she was â€œin a very interesting meetingâ€ the day before we spoke â€œtalking about possible collaborations with the Women and Non-binary network, but that is all that we can give you so far.â€

â€œIt will be a very exciting event, so please keep your eyes open for next term.â€

Ellen spoke about being able to collaborate across YUSU as a Part-time Officer, saying that â€œI have never been able to collaborate in this way before and its really exciting to be a part of it.â€

â€œThis yearâ€™s Part-time Officers are amazing, Iâ€™m really proud of us all especially because all of our networks took a bit of a dip over Covid, but we have all brought them back really well and strongly and we all work together well.â€

She added that â€œThe role of RAG Officer is not what I imagined it would be in the best way possible.â€

Speaking more about the Fashion Show, she said that â€œwe are working together on the sustainable fashion showâ€¦ which is a collaboration with lots of different societiesâ€ including Swap Donâ€™t Shop, Craft Soc, Art Soc, YSTV, Tech Soc, Fashion Soc and Environment Soc.

When Nouse caught up with her ahead of the event she excitedly told us that â€œplanning is going really well at the moment.â€ Before adding that â€œits going to be an absolutely fantastic event. We have Central Hall so it's going to be really big.â€

She also praised the models, stylists and make up artists who signed up to take part in the fashion show and model and style the clothes which have been lent to RAG and Environment and Ethics for this show ahead of being swapped by Swap Donâ€™t Shop.

â€œEveryone has just come together and collaborated really well in a way that neither Anushka or I could have imagined â€¦ itâ€™s a massive collaboration and weâ€™re all really passionate about making sure that everybody is recognised as a result of their workâ€

â€œFrom what we know, it is one of the first big sustainable fashion shows that has happened on campus and we would like it to possibly be an event which is recurring.â€ Ellen and Anushka â€œfeel like we are setting the paving stones for it to happen again in the future.â€

Ellen also told us more about the outfits which were on display saying that â€œwe had never seen the clothes before until the models put them on and its really cool to see them all put them on.â€ Adding that there are â€œso many bizarre outfitsâ€.

Her â€œfavourite theme is outdated trendsâ€ demonstrating â€œhow instead of getting rid of clothes we can use them again.â€ This means that â€œwe have a ton of neon. Iâ€™ve never seen neon be used in so many amazing ways until now and its changed my life. I love neon now.â€

There was an open advert for models to take part in the show. â€œWe made sure that we got a diverse set of models, it was open to absolutely everyone. We really wanted to be as inclusive as possible as everybody wears clothes.â€

Nouse attended the ReFashion Show on 6 November which saw a range of models walk the catwalk wearing a range of Swap Donâ€™t Shop clothes.

Speaking to Anushka Swannell, Environment and Ethics Officer before the event, she said that â€œIâ€™m really excited, the dress rehearsal went really well...itâ€™s been a really long project so to see it all come to life is so beautiful.â€

She added that she hopes the impact of the event will include â€œfruitful collaboration between societies...and raising awareness of the fashion industry and how destructive it is and how you can be a sustainable student in your own way and within your own financial capacity."

The first category saw the models walk to the theme â€˜wearableâ€™ which demonstrated how second-hand clothing can be worn day-to-day and still applies.Â Â Models, who included YUSU Community and Wellbeing Officer, Hannah Nimmo, and LGBTQ+ Part-time Officer, Ziggy, wore a range of jeans, tops, skirts and dresses.

The next theme was â€˜The True Cost of Fashionâ€™ in which Art Society collaborated with the event using their waste materials and decorating the clothes to show the cost of fashion to the environment and those who are involved in making fast fashion. A particular stand out in this category was a jacket worn which had cuffs dyed red.

Finally, the last category was â€˜Outdated trendsâ€™ which saw a lot of double denim and neon and was intended to demonstrate that fashion is cyclical and that clothes do not need to be thrown away once a trend is no-more, rather they can be used again.

Between each category, Ellen and Anushka came on stage to demonstrate the impact of fast fashion on the planet and encourage students to make sustainable choices in their daily lives.They also detailed the work of Fashion Revoluton, the beneficiary for the evening.

A noteworthy aspect was the makeup on display, done by members of Fashion Society, which reflected the bright colours in the clothes.

Speaking to Nouse after the event, Rohan Ashar, YUSU Activities Officer said â€œI think that [the ReFashion show] was absolutely incredible. The amount of talent on show was immense, the messages shared are really important and the amount of work that went into it overall...was incredible.â€
